{{About|Eroticism|the band|E-Rotic|the Madonna song|Erotica (song)}} [[File:Félicien Rops - L'ange.jpg|thumb| ''Der Engel (der Apotheose)'' (between 1878 and 1881) by [[Félicien Rops]]]] {{Wiktionary}} {{Love sidebar}} '''Eroticism''' (from the [[Greek language|Greek]] ἔρως, ''[[Eros (love)|eros]]''—"desire") is a quality that causes [[Human sexuality|sexual]] feelings,<ref name=merriam>{{cite web |title=Eroticism|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/eroticism|work=Merriam-Webster|accessdate=7 August 2011}}</ref> as well as a philosophical contemplation concerning the [[aesthetic]]s of sexual desire, [[sensuality]] and [[romantic love]]. That quality may be found in any form of artwork, including [[painting]], [[sculpture]], [[glamor photography|photography]], [[drama]], [[erotic film|film]], [[music]] or [[erotic literature|literature]]. It may also be found in [[Sex in advertising|advertising]]. The term may also refer to a state of [[sexual arousal]]<ref name=merriam /> or anticipation of such – an insistent sexual [[impulse (psychology)|impulse]], [[libido|desire]], or pattern of thoughts.
As French novelist [[Honoré de Balzac]] stated, eroticism is dependent not just upon an individual's [[Sexual ethics|sexual morality]], but also the culture and time in which an individual resides.<ref>Balzac, "The Physiology of Marriage" (1826), trans. Sharon Marcus (1997), Aphorism XXVI, 65</ref><ref>Grande, L., "Laws and Attitudes towards Homosexuality from Antiquity to the Modern Era", Ponte 43:4-5 (1987), pp. 122-129</ref><ref>Gauthier, Albert, "La sodomie dans le droit canonique medieval" in L'Erotisme au Moyen Age: Etudes presentees au IIe Colloque de l'Institut d'Etudes Medievales, 3-4 Avril 1976, ed. Roy, Bruno (Montreal: Ed. Aurore, 1977), pp. 109-122</ref>
==Definitions== Because the nature of what is erotic is fluid,<ref>Evans, David T., Sexual Citizenship: The Material Construction of Sexualities, (New York: Routledge, 1993)</ref> early definitions of the term attempted to conceive eroticism as some form of sensual or romantic love or as the human sex drive ([[libido]]); for example, the ''Encyclopédie'' of 1755 states that the erotic "is an epithet which is applied to everything with a connection to the love of the sexes; one employs it particularly to characterize...a dissoluteness, an excess".<ref>''Encyclopédie'' (1755), quoted in Lynn Hunt ed., ''Eroticism and the Body Politic'' (London 1991) p. 90</ref>
Because eroticism is wholly dependent on the viewer's culture and personal tastes pertaining to what, exactly, defines the erotic,<ref>Foster. Jeannette H., Sex Variant Women in Literature: A Historical and Quantitative Survey 2nd ed., (New York: Vantage Press, 1956) (repr. Baltimore: Diana Press, 1975)</ref><ref>Weinberg, M., & A. Bell, Homosexuality: An Annotated Bibliography, (New York: 1972)</ref> critics have often{{how often|date=June 2018}} confused eroticism with [[pornography]], with anti-smut activist [[Andrea Dworkin]] saying, "Erotica is simply high-class pornography; better produced, better conceived, better executed, better packaged, designed for a better class of consumer."<ref>{{cite book |title=Pornography: Men Possessing Women |last=Dworkin |first=Andrea |year=1981 |isbn=978-0-399-12619-2 |pages=39}}</ref> This confusion, as [[Lynn Hunt]] writes, "demonstrate the difficulty of drawing… a clear generic demarcation between the erotic and the pornographic": indeed arguably "the history of the separation of pornography from eroticism… remains to be written".<ref>Hunt, "Introduction", in Hunt ed., ''Eroticism'' p. 4</ref>
== Biological evolution == Whereas traditionally eroticism has been dealt with in relation to culture and its pornographic outcomes, current evolutionary psychology shows how eroticism has shaped the evolution of human nature.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Mating Mind: How Sexual Choice Shaped the Evolution of Human Nature|last=Miller|first=Geoffrey|publisher=Vintage|year=2001|isbn=|location=London|pages=|via=}}</ref>
==Psychoanalytical approach== [[File:Édouard-Henri Avril (8).jpg|thumb|left|An erotic scene from ''[[Fanny Hill]]'' by French illustrator [[Édouard-Henri Avril]]]] For a [[psychoanalytical]] definition, as early as [[Freud]]<ref>Dollmore, Jonathan, Sexual Dissidence: Ausgutine to Wilde, Freud to Foucault, (Oxford: Clarendon, 1991)</ref> psychotherapists have turned to the ancient Greek philosophy's "overturning of mythology"{{citation needed|date=August 2011}} as a definition to understanding of the heightened [[aesthetic]].<ref>Hunt, "Introduction", in Hunt ed., Eroticism p. 13</ref> For [[Plato]], [[Eros (mythology)|Eros]] takes an almost [[transcendent (philosophy)|transcendent]] manifestation when the subject seeks to go beyond itself and form a communion with the objectival other: "the true order of going...to the things of love, is to use the beauties of earth as steps...to all fair forms, and from fair forms to fair actions, and from fair actions to fair notions, until from fair notions he arrives at the notion of absolute beauty".<ref>"The Symposium", in Benjamin Jowett trans, ''The Essential Plato'' (1999) p. 746</ref>
==French philosophy== Modern French conceptions of eroticism can be traced to [[The Enlightenment]],<ref>Coward, D.A., "Attitudes to Homosexuality in Eighteenth Century France", Journal of European Studies 10, pp. 236 ff.</ref> when "in the eighteenth century, dictionaries defined the erotic as that which concerned love...eroticism was the intrusion into the public sphere of something that was at base private".<ref>Hunt, "Introduction", in Hunt ed., ''Eroticism'' p. 3 and p. 5</ref> This theme of intrusion or transgression was taken up in the twentieth century by the French philosopher [[Georges Bataille]], who argued that eroticism performs a function of dissolving boundaries between human subjectivity and humanity, a transgression that dissolves the rational world but is always temporary,<ref>L'érotisme, by Georges Bataille, Paris (1957: UK publication 1962) {{ISBN|978-2-7073-0253-3}}</ref> as well as that, "Desire in eroticism is the desire that triumphs over the taboo. It presupposes man in conflict with himself".<ref>George Bataille, ''Eroticism'' (Penguin 2001) p. 256</ref> For Bataille, as well as many French theorists, "Eroticism, unlike simple sexual activity, is a psychological quest...eroticism is assenting to life even in death".<ref>Bataille, ''Eroticism'' p. 11</ref>
==Non-heterosexual== [[File:Ciągliński Symbolic dance.jpg|thumb|right|''Symbolic dance'' by [[Jan Ciągliński]], late 19th-century subtle [[Lesbianism in erotica|lesbian erotica]] ([[National Museum, Warsaw|National Museum]] in [[Warsaw]]).]] [[Queer theory]] and [[LGBT studies]] consider the concept from a [[non-heterosexual]] perspective, viewing psychoanalytical and modernist views of eroticism as both archaic<ref>Morton, Donald, ed., The Material Queer: A LesBiGay Cultural Studies Reader, (Boulder CO: Westview, 1996)</ref> and [[Heterosexism|heterosexist]],<ref>Cohen, Ed, Talk on the Wilde Side: Towards a Genealogy of a Discourse on Male Sexualities, (New York: Routledge, 1999)</ref> written primarily by and for a "handful of elite, heterosexual, bourgeois men"<ref>Flannigan-Saint-Aubin, Arthur. "'Black Gay Male' Discourse: Reading Race and Sexuality Between the Lines". Journal of the History of Sexuality 3:3 (1993): 468-90.</ref> who "mistook their own repressed sexual proclivities"<ref>Aries, Philippe & Andre Bejin, eds., Western Sexuality: Practice and Precept in Past and Present, (Oxford: Blackwell, 1985; orig. pub. as Sexualities Occidentales, Paris: Editions du Seuil/Communications, 1982)</ref> as the norm.<ref>Bullough, Vern L., "Homosexuality and the Medical Model", Journal of Homosexuality 1:6 (1975), pp. 99-110</ref>
Theorists like [[Eve Kosofsky Sedgwick]],<ref>from Abelove, Henry, Michele Aina Barale, and David Halperin, eds., The Lesbian and Gay Studies Reader, (New York: Routledge: 1993) Eve Kosofsky Sedgewick: Epistemology of the closet, 45</ref> [[Gayle S. Rubin]]<ref>from Abelove, Henry, Michele Aina Barale, and David Halperin, eds., The Lesbian and Gay Studies Reader, (New York: Routledge: 1993) Gayle S. Rubin: Notes for a radical theory of the politics of sexuality, 3</ref> and [[Marilyn Frye]]<ref>from Abelove, Henry, Michele Aina Barale, and David Halperin, eds., The Lesbian and Gay Studies Reader, (New York: Routledge: 1993) Marilyn Frye: Some reflections on separatism and power, 91</ref> all write extensively about eroticism from a heterosexual, [[lesbian]] and [[separatist]] point of view, respectively, seeing Eroticism as both a political force<ref>Marshall, John, "Pansies, Perverts and Macho Men: Changing Conceptions of Male Homosexuality", in Kenneth Plummer, ed., The Making of the Modern Homosexual, (London: Hutchinson, 1981), 133-54</ref> and cultural critique<ref>Fone, Byrne R.S., "Some Notes Toward a History of Gay People", The Advocate no. 259 (Jan 25, 1979), pp. 17-19 & no. 260 (Feb 28, 1979), pp. 11-13</ref> for marginalized groups, or as [[Mario Vargas Llosa]] summarized: "Eroticism has its own moral justification because it says that pleasure is enough for me; it is a statement of the individual's sovereignty".<ref>Mangan, J. A. "Men, Masculinity, and Sexuality: Some Recent Literature". Journal of the History of Sexuality 3:2 (1992): 303-13</ref>
[[Audre Lorde]], a Caribbean-American writer and out-spoken [[Feminism|feminist]] talks of the erotic being a type of power being specific to females. "There are many kinds of power [...] The erotic is a resource within each of us that lies in a deeply female and spiritual plane, firmly rooted in the power of our unexpressed or unrecognized feelings".<ref>{{cite book |title=Sister Outsider: Essays and Speeches |last=Lorde |first=Audre |last2=Clarke |first2=Cheryl |publisher=Ten Speed Press |year=2007 |origyear=1984 |isbn=978-1-58091-186-3 |location=New York |pages=53}}</ref> In "The Uses of the Erotic" within ''[[Sister Outsider]]'', she discusses how erotic comes from sharing, but if we suppress the erotic rather than recognize its presence, it takes on a different form. Rather than enjoying and sharing with one another, it is objectifying, which she says translates into abuse as we attempt to hide and suppress our experiences.<ref>{{Cite book|title = SIster Outsider|last = Lorde|first = Audre|publisher = Ten Speed Press|year = 2007|isbn = |location = NY|pages = 53–58|chapter = Uses of the Erotic: The Erotic As Power (1984)}}</ref>

In algebra, a '''generic matrix ring''' is a sort of a universal [[matrix ring]].
== Definition == We denote by <math>F_n</math> a generic matrix ring of size ''n'' with variables <math>X_1, \dots X_m</math>. It is characterized by the universal property: given a commutative ring ''R'' and ''n''-by-''n'' matrices <math>A_1, \dots, A_m</math> over ''R'', any mapping <math>X_i \mapsto A_i</math> extends to the [[ring homomorphism]] (called evaluation) <math>F_n \to M_n(R)</math>.
Explicitly, given a field ''k'', it is the subalgebra <math>F_n</math> of the matrix ring <math>M_n(k[(X_l)_{ij}|1 \le l \le m, 1 \le i, j \le n])</math> generated by ''n''-by-''n'' matrices <math>X_1, \dots, X_m</math>, where <math>(X_l)_{ij}</math> are matrix entries and commute by definition. For example, if ''m'' = 1, then <math>F_1</math> is a polynomial ring in one variable.
For example, a [[central polynomial]] is an element of the ring <math>F_n</math> that will map to a central element under an evaluation. (In fact, it is in the [[invariant ring]] <math>k[(X_l)_{ij}]^{\operatorname{GL}_n(k)}</math> since it is central and invariant.<ref>{{harvnb|Artin|1999|loc=Proposition V.15.2.}}</ref>)
By definition, <math>F_n</math> is a quotient of the [[free ring]] <math>k\langle t_1, \dots, t_m \rangle</math> with <math>t_i \mapsto X_i</math> by the ideal consisting of all ''p'' that vanish identically on any ''n''-by-''n'' matrices over ''k''.
== Geometric perspective == The universal property means that any ring homomorphism from <math>k\langle t_1, \dots, t_m \rangle</math> to a matrix ring factors through <math>F_n</math>. This has a following geometric meaning. In algebraic geometry, the polynomial ring <math>k[t, \dots, t_m]</math> is the coordinate ring of the affine space <math>k^m</math> and to give a point of <math>k^m</math> is to give a ring homomorphism (evaluation) <math>k[t, \dots, t_m] \to k</math> (either by the [[Hilbert nullstellensatz]] or by the [[scheme theory]]). The free ring <math>k\langle t_1, \dots, t_m \rangle</math> plays the role of the coordinate ring of the affine space in the [[noncommutative algebraic geometry]] (i.e., we don't demand free variables to commute) and thus a generic matrix ring of size ''n'' is the coordinate ring of a noncommutative affine variety whose points are the Spec's of matrix rings of size ''n'' (see below for a more concrete discussion.)
=== The maximal spectrum of a generic matrix ring === {{expand section|date=June 2014}}
For simplicity, assume ''k'' is algebraically closed. Let ''A'' be an algebra over ''k'' and let <math>\operatorname{Spec}_n(A)</math> denote the set of all maximal ideals <math>\mathfrak{m}</math> in ''A'' such that <math>A/\mathfrak{m} \approx M_n(k)</math>. If ''A'' is commutative, then <math>\operatorname{Spec}_1(A)</math> is the [[maximal spectrum]] of ''A'' and <math>\operatorname{Spec}_n(A)</math> is empty for any <math>n > 1</math>.
